name: collections::btree::node::Handle::<collections::btree::node::NodeRef<collections::btree::node::marker::Mut<'a>, K, V, collections::btree::node::marker::Internal>, collections::btree::node::marker::KV>::split

collections::btree::node::NodeRef::<Borr.doc:
Finds the length of the node. This is the number of keys or values.
 The number of edges is `len() + 1`.
 Note that, despite being safe, calling this function can have the side effect
 of invalidating mutable references that unsafe code has created.

collections::btree::node::InternalNode::.doc:
Creates a new boxed `InternalNode`.

 # Safety
 An invariant of internal nodes is that they have at least one
 initialized and valid edge. This function does not set up
 such an edge.

collections::btree::node::Handle::<colle.doc:
Helps implementations of `split` for a particular `NodeType`,
 by taking care of leaf data.

core::convert::From::from.doc: Converts to this type from the input type.

collections::btree::node::NodeRef::<coll.doc:
Borrows exclusive access to an element or slice of the node's storage area for edge contents.

 # Safety
 `index` is in bounds of 0..CAPACITY + 1

core::ops::IndexMut::index_mut.doc:
Performs the mutable indexing (`container[index]`) operation.

 # Panics

 May panic if the index is out of bounds.

collections::btree::node::move_to_slice.doc:
Moves all values from a slice of initialized elements to a slice
 of uninitialized elements, leaving behind `src` as all uninitialized.
 Works like `dst.copy_from_slice(src)` but does not require `T` to be `Copy`.

core::num::NonZero::<T>::new_unchecked.doc:
Creates a non-zero without checking whether the value is non-zero.
 This results in undefined behavior if the value is zero.

 # Safety

 The value must not be zero.

collections::btree::node::NodeRef::<coll.doc: Creates a new internal (height > 0) `NodeRef` from an existing internal node

doc:
Splits the underlying node into three parts:

 - The node is truncated to only contain the edges and key-value pairs to the
   left of this handle.
 - The key and value pointed to by this handle are extracted.
 - All the edges and key-value pairs to the right of this handle are put into
   a newly allocated node.
